roi.title: ROI Calculator

info.title: About ROI
info.description: ROI measures the gain or loss generated on an investment relative to the amount of money invested.

howItWorks.title: How ROI Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: ROI = ((Final Value - Initial Investment) / Initial Investment) × 100
howItWorks.explanation: ROI measures the percentage return on an investment by comparing the gain or loss to the initial cost. Annualized ROI adjusts for the investment period to enable fair comparisons between investments of different durations.
steps: Enter the initial investment amount
Input the final or current value of the investment
Specify the investment period in years
Calculator computes total and annualized ROI
Review the net profit and payback analysis

seoTips: Always use annualized ROI when comparing investments with different time horizons
Include all associated costs (fees, maintenance, taxes) for accurate ROI calculation
Compare ROI against benchmark returns like market indices or savings rates
Consider risk-adjusted returns - higher risk should demand higher ROI
Track ROI over time to identify trends and optimize future investments

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Time Value of Money
commonMistakes.description: Simple ROI doesn't account for when returns occur. A 20% return over 5 years is very different from 20% in 1 year. Use annualized ROI for comparison.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Hidden Costs
commonMistakes.description: Transaction fees, maintenance costs, taxes, and opportunity costs are often excluded, leading to overstated ROI figures.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Risk
commonMistakes.description: Two investments with the same ROI may have vastly different risk profiles. Higher risk should justify higher expected returns.

commonMistakes.title: Cherry-Picking Time Periods
commonMistakes.description: Selecting favorable start and end dates can manipulate ROI figures. Use consistent, meaningful time periods for fair analysis.

faqs.question: What is a good ROI?
faqs.answer: Good ROI depends on context. Stock market historically averages 7-10% annually. Real estate targets 8-12%. Business investments often require 15-25% to justify the risk.

faqs.question: What's the difference between ROI and CAGR?
faqs.answer: ROI shows total return as a percentage. CAGR (Compound Annual Growth Rate) shows the smoothed annual return accounting for compounding. CAGR is better for comparing multi-year investments.

faqs.question: Can ROI be negative?
faqs.answer: Yes, negative ROI indicates a loss. If you invest $10,000 and it's worth $8,000, your ROI is -20%. This helps quantify investment losses.

faqs.question: How do I calculate ROI for ongoing investments?
faqs.answer: Use current market value as the 'final value' for unrealized gains. Include any dividends, interest, or distributions received during the holding period.

faqs.question: Should I include inflation in ROI calculations?
faqs.answer: For accurate purchasing power analysis, calculate real ROI by subtracting inflation from nominal ROI. A 10% return with 3% inflation yields 7% real return.

howItWorks.title: How NPV Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: NPV = Σ(Cash Flow / (1 + r)^t) - Initial Investment
howItWorks.explanation: NPV calculates the present value of all future cash flows, discounted at a required rate of return, minus the initial investment. A positive NPV indicates the investment should generate value; negative NPV suggests the investment will destroy value.
steps: Enter the initial investment amount
Set your discount rate (cost of capital or required return)
Input expected cash flows for each future year
Calculator discounts each cash flow to present value
NPV = sum of discounted cash flows minus initial investment

commonMistakes.title: Using Wrong Discount Rate
commonMistakes.description: The discount rate should reflect the risk of the cash flows. Using a rate too low overstates NPV; too high understates it.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Terminal Value

commonMistakes.title: Overly Optimistic Cash Flows

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Inflation
commonMistakes.description: Either use nominal cash flows with nominal discount rate, or real cash flows with real rate. Mixing them creates errors.

faqs.question: What does positive NPV mean?
faqs.answer: Positive NPV means the investment is expected to generate more value than its cost. It should increase company/investor wealth and is generally worth pursuing.

faqs.question: What discount rate should I use?
faqs.answer: Use your cost of capital or required rate of return. For companies, WACC (7-12% typical). For personal investments, consider opportunity cost and risk.

faqs.question: What's the difference between NPV and IRR?
faqs.answer: NPV gives dollar value created; IRR gives percentage return. NPV is generally preferred because it measures absolute value creation, not just rate.

faqs.question: Can NPV be negative?
faqs.answer: Yes. Negative NPV means the investment is expected to destroy value - the present value of returns is less than the cost. Generally avoid negative NPV projects.

faqs.question: How do I include terminal value in NPV?
faqs.answer: Estimate ongoing value at end of projection period (often using perpetuity formula or exit multiple), then discount that terminal value back to present.

howItWorks.title: How IRR Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: IRR = Discount rate where NPV equals zero
howItWorks.explanation: IRR (Internal Rate of Return) is the discount rate that makes the net present value of all cash flows equal to zero. It represents the annualized rate of return on an investment, allowing comparison between projects of different sizes and durations.
steps: Enter the initial investment amount (as a negative cash flow)
Input expected cash flows for each future year
Calculator iteratively finds the rate where NPV = 0
Result shows the IRR as an annual percentage
Compare IRR to your required return or cost of capital

commonMistakes.title: Assuming Reinvestment at IRR
commonMistakes.description: IRR assumes cash flows are reinvested at the IRR rate, which may be unrealistic for high-IRR projects.

commonMistakes.title: Multiple IRR Problem
commonMistakes.description: Projects with alternating positive and negative cash flows can have multiple IRRs, making interpretation difficult.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Scale
commonMistakes.description: A small project with high IRR may create less value than a large project with lower IRR. Consider NPV alongside IRR.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Different Duration Projects
commonMistakes.description: A 2-year project with 20% IRR isn't directly comparable to a 10-year project with 15% IRR. Consider total value creation.

faqs.question: What is a good IRR?
faqs.answer: Depends on risk and alternatives. Generally: above risk-free rate (3-5%) is minimum, above cost of capital (8-12%) is acceptable, above 15-20% is good for most investments.

faqs.question: What's the difference between IRR and ROI?
faqs.answer: ROI is simple total return (profit/cost). IRR accounts for time value of money and timing of cash flows. IRR is annualized; ROI is total return regardless of period.

faqs.question: When should I use IRR vs NPV?
faqs.answer: Use both. IRR tells return rate; NPV tells dollar value created. For mutually exclusive projects, NPV is preferred. For quick comparison, IRR is useful.

faqs.question: What is Modified IRR (MIRR)?
faqs.answer: MIRR assumes cash flows are reinvested at cost of capital rather than at IRR. It's more realistic for high-IRR projects and avoids multiple IRR issues.

faqs.question: Why can't IRR be calculated for my project?
faqs.answer: IRR requires at least one sign change in cash flows (typically negative investment followed by positive returns). All positive or all negative flows have no IRR.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Profit with Cash Flow
commonMistakes.description: Net income includes non-cash items like depreciation and accounts receivable. A profitable business can run out of cash.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Timing

commonMistakes.title: Overlooking Seasonal Variations
commonMistakes.description: Annual cash flow may be positive while individual months are negative. Plan for seasonal patterns.

commonMistakes.title: Not Including All Cash Items
commonMistakes.description: Don't forget loan payments, tax payments, owner draws, and one-time expenses that affect cash but may not appear on income statement.

faqs.question: What's the difference between cash flow and profit?
faqs.answer: Profit includes non-cash items like depreciation and accrued revenue. Cash flow tracks actual money movement. A company can be profitable but cash-poor, or cash-rich but unprofitable.

faqs.question: What is operating cash flow?
faqs.answer: Cash from core business operations - customer payments minus operating expenses. It excludes investing (buying/selling assets) and financing (loans, equity) activities.

faqs.question: How can I improve cash flow?
faqs.answer: Collect receivables faster, negotiate longer payment terms with suppliers, reduce inventory levels, lease instead of buy equipment, and manage growth pace.

faqs.question: What is free cash flow?
faqs.answer: Operating cash flow minus capital expenditures. It's cash available for dividends, debt reduction, or reinvestment after maintaining operations.

faqs.question: How often should I review cash flow?
faqs.answer: Weekly for short-term management, monthly for trends, quarterly for strategic planning. More frequently during tight cash periods.

commonMistakes.title: Using Short-Term Rates for Long-Term Planning
commonMistakes.description: Current inflation rates may be temporary. Use long-term averages (2-3%) for retirement and multi-decade planning.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Inflation Entirely
commonMistakes.description: Planning retirement needs at today's costs without inflation adjustment leads to severe shortfalls.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Sector-Specific Inflation
commonMistakes.description: Healthcare, education, and housing often inflate faster than general CPI. Account for your specific expense mix.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Nominal and Real Values
commonMistakes.description: Investment returns, salaries, and prices are usually quoted nominally. Subtract inflation for real (inflation-adjusted) values.

faqs.question: What is a realistic inflation rate to use?
faqs.answer: For long-term planning, 2.5-3% is reasonable based on historical averages. Central banks typically target 2%. Adjust based on current economic conditions.

faqs.question: How does inflation affect my savings?
faqs.answer: If your savings earn less than inflation, you're losing purchasing power. $10,000 at 1% interest with 3% inflation loses real value each year.

faqs.question: What is the Rule of 72 for inflation?
faqs.answer: Divide 72 by the inflation rate to see how many years until prices double. At 3% inflation: 72/3 = 24 years for prices to double.

faqs.question: Should I invest differently based on inflation?
faqs.answer: Yes. During high inflation, consider TIPS, I-bonds, real estate, commodities, and stocks. Cash and fixed bonds lose value in high inflation.

faqs.question: What is deflation and how is it different?
faqs.answer: Deflation is negative inflation - prices decrease over time. Rare but harmful to economies. Your money gains purchasing power but economic activity slows.

faqs.question: What is an earnings multiplier?
faqs.answer: A multiplier represents how many years of earnings a buyer will pay. A 4x multiplier means paying 4 years of profit upfront for the business.

faqs.question: How do I determine the right multiplier?
faqs.answer: Research comparable business sales in your industry. Factors include growth rate, recurring revenue, market position, risk, and owner dependency.

faqs.question: What is SDE (Seller's Discretionary Earnings)?
faqs.answer: SDE is net profit plus owner salary, owner benefits, and one-time or non-recurring expenses. It represents cash flow available to a new owner.

faqs.question: When should I get a professional valuation?
faqs.answer: For serious sale or purchase decisions, partnership disputes, or divorce proceedings. Professional valuations cost $3,000-20,000 but provide defensible values.

faqs.question: How can I increase my business value?
faqs.answer: Increase profitability, build recurring revenue, reduce owner dependency, diversify customer base, document processes, and maintain clean financials.

faqs.question: How much do I need for retirement?
faqs.answer: Common rule: 25x annual expenses (4% withdrawal rate). If you spend $50,000/year, target $1.25 million. Adjust for Social Security and pensions.

faqs.question: What rate of return should I use?
faqs.answer: Conservative: 5-6%. Moderate: 7%. Aggressive: 8-9%. Use lower rates as you approach retirement when you should be more conservative.

faqs.question: When should I start saving for retirement?
faqs.answer: As early as possible. Starting at 25 vs 35 can mean twice as much at retirement due to compound interest - time is your biggest advantage.

faqs.question: What is the 4% rule?
faqs.answer: Research suggests withdrawing 4% of savings annually has a high probability of lasting 30+ years. So $1M allows ~$40K/year withdrawals.

faqs.question: How do I account for Social Security?
faqs.answer: Estimate your Social Security benefit and subtract from needed income. You need to save enough to cover the gap between Social Security and total needs.

faqs.question: What is employer matching?
faqs.answer: Employer contributes to your 401(k) based on your contribution. Common match: 50% of your contribution up to 6% of salary. So 6% contribution gets 3% employer match.

faqs.question: How much should I contribute to 401(k)?
faqs.answer: At minimum, enough to get full employer match. Ideally 15-20% of income including match. Max out ($23,000 in 2024) if you can afford it.

faqs.question: What is 401(k) vesting?
faqs.answer: Vesting determines when employer match becomes yours. You may need to work 3-6 years to be fully vested. Your contributions are always 100% yours.

faqs.question: Traditional vs Roth 401(k)?
faqs.answer: Traditional: Pre-tax contributions, taxed at withdrawal. Roth: After-tax contributions, tax-free withdrawal. Choose based on current vs expected future tax rates.

faqs.question: Can I withdraw early from 401(k)?
faqs.answer: Early withdrawal (before 59.5) incurs 10% penalty plus income tax. Exceptions exist for hardship, disability, and certain other situations.

Appraisal value may differ from purchase price - lender uses lower of the two
Combined LTV (CLTV) includes all loans secured by the property
FHA loans allow up to 96.5% LTV; VA loans allow 100% LTV

commonMistakes.title: Using Purchase Price Instead of Appraisal
commonMistakes.description: Lenders use the lower of purchase price or appraised value. An appraisal below purchase price increases your LTV.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting About PMI Cost
commonMistakes.description: PMI at higher LTV can cost $100-300/month. Calculate total monthly payment, not just principal and interest.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Combined LTV
commonMistakes.description: If you have a HELOC or second mortgage, combined LTV matters. All loans against the property count.

commonMistakes.title: Not Planning for 80% Threshold
commonMistakes.description: Getting close to 80% but not reaching it still requires PMI. Better to hit exactly 80% than 81%.

faqs.question: What is a good LTV ratio?
faqs.answer: 80% or below is ideal - no PMI, best rates. 80-90% is acceptable but requires PMI. Above 90% is high risk with higher rates.

faqs.question: What is PMI and why does LTV matter?
faqs.answer: Private Mortgage Insurance protects lenders if you default. Required when LTV exceeds 80%. Costs 0.5-1% of loan annually until you reach 80% equity.

faqs.question: How do I lower my LTV?
faqs.answer: Make a larger down payment, pay down principal faster, or wait for property appreciation. Refinancing after significant principal paydown or appreciation can help.

faqs.question: When can I remove PMI?
faqs.answer: When LTV reaches 80% through payments, or automatically removed at 78% LTV. You can request removal at 80% with good payment history.

faqs.question: Does LTV affect my interest rate?
faqs.answer: Yes. Lower LTV usually means lower rates. Rates may improve at 80%, 75%, and 60% LTV thresholds depending on lender.

payback_period.title: Payback Period Calculator

inputs.initial_investment_tooltip: Cost of the project or asset
inputs.salvage_value_tooltip: Residual value at end of life

results.formula: Payback Period = (Investment - Salvage) / Annual Cash Flow

info.title: About Payback Period
info.description: The payback period is the length of time required to recover the cost of an investment.

howItWorks.title: How Payback Period Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Payback Period = Initial Investment / Annual Cash Flow
howItWorks.explanation: The payback period measures how long it takes to recover the initial investment from cash flows generated by the project. Shorter payback periods indicate lower risk as the investment is recovered sooner, but this metric ignores the time value of money and cash flows beyond the payback point.
steps: Enter the initial investment amount
Input the expected annual cash flow from the investment
Optionally add salvage value for equipment investments
Calculator divides net investment by annual cash flow
Result shows years and months to recover the investment

useCases.title: Capital Budgeting
useCases.description: Compare investment opportunities by how quickly they return the initial capital, prioritizing faster payback projects.

useCases.title: Risk Assessment
useCases.description: Shorter payback periods reduce exposure to uncertainty, making payback a useful risk screening tool.

useCases.title: Cash Flow Planning
useCases.description: Understand when invested capital will be available for reinvestment in other opportunities.

useCases.title: Equipment Purchase Decisions
useCases.description: Evaluate whether new equipment will pay for itself within an acceptable timeframe before becoming obsolete.

seoTips: Shorter payback periods generally indicate lower risk investments
Use payback period alongside NPV and IRR for comprehensive analysis
Consider industry-specific acceptable payback periods - technology may require faster payback
Account for inflation when projecting future cash flows
Remember that payback ignores profitability beyond the break-even point

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Cash Flows After Payback
commonMistakes.description: Payback period doesn't consider returns generated after the investment is recovered. A project with longer payback may still be more profitable overall.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Time Value of Money
commonMistakes.description: Simple payback treats all cash flows equally. Use discounted payback period for more accurate analysis of present value.

commonMistakes.title: Using Average Instead of Actual Cash Flows
commonMistakes.description: If cash flows vary year to year, using averages can misrepresent actual payback timing.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Initial Setup Costs
commonMistakes.description: Include all upfront costs - installation, training, transition expenses - not just the purchase price.

faqs.question: What is a good payback period?
faqs.answer: Depends on the industry and investment type. Generally, 2-3 years is good for equipment, 3-5 years for larger projects. High-risk investments should have shorter payback periods.

faqs.question: What's the difference between payback period and ROI?
faqs.answer: Payback period measures time to recover investment. ROI measures total return as a percentage. A short payback doesn't guarantee good ROI, and vice versa.

faqs.question: Should I always choose the shortest payback period?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Short payback reduces risk but may not maximize returns. Consider total profitability alongside payback when making decisions.

faqs.question: How do I calculate payback with uneven cash flows?
faqs.answer: Add cash flows year by year until cumulative cash equals initial investment. Payback occurs when the running total reaches zero.

faqs.question: What is discounted payback period?
faqs.answer: Discounted payback accounts for time value of money by discounting future cash flows before calculating when they recover the investment.
